page.title: 02OKEHAMPTON CASTLE
page.content: After the Battle of Hastings, risings in the west were harshly suppressed. A strong hold at Okehampton seemed a necessity for Baldwin FitzGilbert. It was partly chosen for its site in the gap between moor and hill, at the joining of several routes westward, but also because Baldwin held many manors in this area. The Castle was rebuilt around 1180 to suit its new owner the Courtnays, who held it for the 350 years. In 1538 the Marquis of Exeter was beheaded for conspiracy and his Castle ordered to be dismantled. It has been a ruin ever since. Late last century it was bought by Mr S. Simmons, and is now entrusted to the Department of the Environment. The custodian, Harry Palmer, is a local figure often seen riding his bicycle around town if he isn't looking after his Castle and his ducks!
